title: Leadership and the people of God

children.title: apologetics
children.comment: The art of explaining the faith in such a way as to make a reasoned defence against its detractors. Paul's Areopagus sermon is a classic example of biblical apologetics, which can be of value to all who are called upon to defend the faith today.

cschildren.title: Paul's Areopagus sermon, a classic example of biblical apologetics

children.title: Paul speaks to his listeners on their own ground, starting on their own terms
Paul supports his argument in a culturally appropriate way

primaryrefs.comment: Paul quotes from two secular writers, first from the Cretan poet Epimenides, and secondly from the Cilician poet Aratus.

children.title: Paul concludes his argument and calls for a response

cschildren.title: Apologetics as a regular feature of Paul's ministry
Apologetics is part of the work of church leaders
All Christians share responsibility for the task of apologetics
Other examples of Christians engaging in apologetics
Apologetics alone is an inadequate way of presenting the gospel

children.title: apostles
children.comment: Appointed representatives, deriving authority and responsibilities from the person or group represented. The word refers especially to Jesus Christ's twelve disciples and also to Paul. Scripture identifies the functions of apostles and their authority, which is derived directly from Jesus Christ.

children.title: apostles, designation of
children.comment: An apostle is one who is ``sent'' by Jesus Christ. The word is used to refer especially to the inner circle of Christ's twelve disciples, but is also used specifically to refer to Paul, who was commissioned as an apostle by the risen Christ. The term is also applied more loosely to certain other leading Christians in the NT period.

primaryrefs.comment: This is the only place where the word ``apostle'' is used of Jesus Christ, though many passages refer to him as ``sent''
Jesus Christ, as God's ``sent one'', sets the standard and pattern for all who are likewise ``sent'' (i.e., for all apostolic ministry).

children.title: The twelve apostles called by Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: ``the Twelve'' is frequently used to designate these specially chosen disciples. The number twelve evokes the twelve tribes of Israel.

children.title: Their commissioning by the risen Christ

seealsos.comment: The symbolic number (twelve) is thus preserved.

children.title: The qualifications for being an apostle

secondaryrefs.comment: Although not one of the Twelve, Paul saw the risen Christ and was directly commissioned by him, sent especially to the Gentiles

primaryrefs.comment: In Paul's case the sense of title or office and the ministry and function virtually coincide. He is an apostle both because he has seen and been commissioned by the risen Christ and because he functioned as an apostle by founding churches.

children.title: Barnabas
children.precomment: Here ``apostles'' may refer to their ministry as missionary evangelists or to their role as ``sent'' by the church at Antioch:

secondaryrefs.comment: The most natural meaning of the words is that James is an apostle. This interpretation is confirmed by other references to James
``representatives'' is the translation here for ``apostles''
``messenger'' is the translation here for ``apostle''
Paul ironically refers to his opponents as ``super-apostles''

children.title: apostles, function of
children.comment: In the NT apostles are servants, first of Jesus Christ and then of the church. Apostolic service embraces a wide range of specific functions.

children.title: The functions of apostles during the earthly life and ministry of Jesus Christ
Being sent out on a mission by Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: As Jesus Christ's representatives their ministry was an extension of his.

children.title: Being commissioned to witness to Jesus Christ
They were witnesses of the resurrection
They were servants of Jesus Christ
They were servants of the church
They were the foundations of the church

primaryrefs.comment: Probably a reference to the apostolic preaching. The absence of the article before ``prophets'' suggests that ``the apostles and prophets'' represents one group of people, not two.

seealsos.comment: the prophetic ministry of the apostles

children.title: They were guardians and teachers of the truth
They were authority figures within the church

secondaryrefs.comment: The apostles took the initiative. Whilst they did not themselves appoint the Seven, they confirmed their appointment.

children.title: They were empowered by the Spirit
They were able to bestow the Spirit

secondaryrefs.comment: Peter and John officially induct Samaritans as members of the body of Christ

children.title: apostles, authority of
children.comment: Apostolic authority derives directly from Jesus Christ, who commissions apostles. It is rigorously upheld within the church.

children.title: Apostolic authority is based on divine commission
Apostolic authority derives from Jesus Christ
The authority of apostles is related to their ministry role

primaryrefs.comment: There appears to be a definite order of priority with apostles at the head.

children.title: The exercise of apostolic authority within the church

primaryrefs.comment: Paul had special authority as founder of this church.
Paul did not demand such support (see 1Th 2:9).

children.title: The marks of a true apostle

children.title: The marks of a true apostle
convincing
children.comment: Persuading one's hearers of the truth of one's case. Scripture gives examples of people who have been convinced of the truth of God's word and of the gospel.

cschildren.title: Examples of prophets convincing their hearers
Hardness of heart can prevent individuals from being convinced of the truth
Examples of individuals convinced of the truth of the gospel

children.title: Paul sought to convince others of the truth of the gospel
deacons
children.comment: Those who ``serve'' in the Christian community, assisting the elders or overseers (bishops). The Greek word which the NIV translates four times as ``deacon'' occurs a further 25 times in the NT, where it is translated as ``servant''. It seems that all Christians have a general servant role, whereas some (deacons) are called to a specific office of service within the church.

cschildren.title: The Seven: assistants to the apostles

primaryrefs.comment: The verb ``wait'' means ``to serve''.
Although the Seven are not actually called ``deacons'', they were probably the earliest example of Christians carrying out the tasks which came to be linked with deacons.

cschildren.title: Deacons were assistants to overseers in Philippi

primaryrefs.comment: All Christians are ``saints'' (that is, set apart for God), but overseers and deacons have specific roles assigned to them.

cschildren.title: Qualifications for men and women deacons

primaryrefs.comment: There is no NT description of the precise role of deacons (although Ac 6:1-4 may imply a certain role). These qualifications would be appropriate for people responsible for financial management, administration, and social service, such as that offered to widows
The women may be deacons' wives (NIV text), or deaconesses (NIV footnote).

cschildren.title: Phoebe, a deaconess

primaryrefs.comment: NIV footnote.

children.title: elders
children.comment: Senior figures within Israel and the Christian church who are given special responsibilities for their people.

children.title: elders, as community leaders
children.comment: Since older men act as responsible leaders in many communities, ``elder'' is used as the title for a recognised leader.

children.title: Elders met in a national assembly
Elders functioned as judges, sometimes in the town gate
Elders during the period of the monarchy
Elders were local representatives at national functions
Elders functioned as judges at the town gate
Elders in Israel during and after the exile
Elders were local town and synagogue leaders
Elders were members of the Sanhedrin
Elders were guardians of religious traditions
The elders' rejection of Jesus Christ predicted by him
The involvement of the elders in the trial and condemnation of Jesus Christ
The elders' involvement with the first Christians
elders, in the church
children.comment: In the NT a group of leaders responsible for managing and teaching a local church. As the name implies, they were normally men of experience and maturity. Although women played a very significant part in early Christian ministry, there is no specific NT evidence for women as elders.

primaryrefs.comment: In Ac 20:17 they are described as ``elders''. Here they are ``overseers''.

children.title: Elders are appointed by apostles or their delegates

primaryrefs.comment: Here, as always in the NT, people are appointed to a joint eldership. There is no NT example of a single elder leading a church.
As in Ac 20:17,28, ``elder'' is here synonymous with ``overseer''.

children.title: As pastors and guardians against false teaching
The remuneration and correction of elders
Elders are to receive respect and submission from church members

primaryrefs.comment: ``leaders'' is an alternative term for ``elders''.

children.title: The elders are seated on thrones

primaryrefs.comment: These elders may be angelic beings corresponding to the 24 orders of Levites (1Chronicles chapters 24-25) or symbolise Israel and the church (compare Rev 21:12-14).

children.title: The elders worship God and the Lamb

children.comment: Since older men act as responsible leaders in many communities, ``elder'' is used as the title for a recognised leader.

evangelists
children.comment: Those called by God to announce good news and, especially, to proclaim the good news of Jesus Christ. The work was first committed to the apostles and then to other believers gifted by the Holy Spirit for the task.

children.title: evangelists, identity of
children.comment: Some OT figures announced good news, but most evangelists are seen in the NT. The task was first given by Jesus Christ to the apostles and then to other believers. All Christians have a part in evangelism; there is, too, a special role of evangelist within the church, fulfilled by those with a particular gifting from the Holy Spirit.

children.title: An evangelist as one who announces good news
God as an announcer of good news

primaryrefs.comment: The good news of the end of the Babylonian exile.

seealsos.comment: the good news of the deliverance from Assyria

children.title: John the Baptist announces good news
Jesus Christ sends out the Twelve

seealsos.comment: Peter and John preach the gospel in Samaria
Peter preaches the gospel to Cornelius.

primaryrefs.comment: Timothy's calling includes that of an evangelist.

seealsos.comment: Priscilla and Aquila

children.title: evangelists, ministry of
children.comment: Evangelists proclaim the good news of Jesus Christ, calling those who hear to believe in him. This may be in the context of missionary journeys, often in partnership with others, or within a more settled ministry. Carrying out the task requires integrity and commitment in the face of hardships and danger; it also brings joy at seeing the church grow.

children.title: Testifying to the truth about Jesus Christ
Calling people to believe in Jesus Christ
The context of the evangelist's work
Within a settled period of ministry

primaryrefs.comment: Timothy as a pastor is also to do the work of an evangelist.

seealsos.comment: Paul spends a year and a half in Corinth
Paul preaches the gospel whilst under house arrest in Rome

children.title: Working so as not to be a burden
Joy at seeing the church grow
The satisfaction of seeing new converts grow in their faith

explanation
children.comment: The provision of the understanding of a dream, vision, parable, teaching or other matter, the meaning of which is less than obvious.

cschildren.title: Examples of the explanation of dreams
Examples of the explanation of visions
Jesus Christ gave his disciples explanations

children.title: Of the Scriptures referring to himself and his relationship to his Father
Of his suffering, death and resurrection

cschildren.title: The gospel was explained

secondaryrefs.comment: by Aquila and Priscilla

cschildren.title: Examples of other explanations

secondaryrefs.comment: The Philistines desperately wanted the answer to Samson's riddle.

children.title: leaders
children.comment: God calls individuals to positions of leadership, both spiritual and political. Such leadership is seen as carrying responsibilities towards both God and his people and is to be exercised with humility.

children.title: leaders, spiritual
children.comment: Under the old covenant God called priests and prophets as spiritual leaders. Later the Pharisees gave spiritual leadership. After Jesus Christ had inaugurated the new covenant, authority was given to the apostles, who in turn appointed leaders in the churches they founded.

children.title: The high priest represented the people in the presence of God
Priests taught and explained God's law
Examples of priests as spiritual leaders

secondaryrefs.comment: The priest Eli was described as leading Israel
Samuel acted as priest on behalf of the people
Jehoiada the priest influenced Joash to serve God.

children.title: Examples of prophets as spiritual leaders
children.precomment: Samuel led the people from idolatry back to the worship of God:

secondaryrefs.comment: Elijah
Haggai
officially recognised teachers of the law
At a local level, elders had social and religious authority in local councils. Nationally, they were included in the Sanhedrin
Jesus Christ taught his disciples the qualities required for spiritual leadership.

children.title: leaders, political
children.comment: Since God is the ultimate ruler of all things, earthly authority derives from him. Although political leadership was exercised in various ways in Israel, there was always some overlap between political and spiritual leadership.

children.title: Israel had a variety of political leaders
Foreign powers imposed rulers on Israel
Examples of those who were both political and spiritual leaders

primaryrefs.comment: Samuel was both prophet and judge.

secondaryrefs.comment: Gideon
Hezekiah
David

children.title: Political leaders, like spiritual ones, were called by God

primaryrefs.comment: The prophet Ahijah confers authority on the leader of a revolt.

seealsos.comment: Moses
Gideon
Cyrus was a Persian king, yet he is described as God's ``anointed''.

children.title: To reject God's leadership is to reject God

seealsos.comment: Israel wanted a human ruler so that they might be like the surrounding nations.

primaryrefs.comment: Being anointed by the Spirit of God.

secondaryrefs.comment: trustworthiness
wisdom

children.title: Through trusting in alliances with heathen powers
People must have a right attitude to political leaders
But obedience to God must come first
Prayers are to be made for them

missionaries
children.comment: Those called and commissioned by God to fulfil specific tasks, especially that of taking the gospel to those who have not heard it. Missionaries may be sent to other towns, cities or nations, or may be called to fulfil their task closer to home.

children.title: missionaries, call of
children.comment: God calls and sends out his people into the world. All believers are called to share the good news of the gospel, though some are specially commissioned by God, confirmed by the church and compelled by the gospel message to missionary service.

children.title: The call to all God's people
Those sent to their own people

seealsos.comment: Noah
Jeremiah's ministry extended further but was primarily to his own people, Judah
Ezekiel

primaryrefs.comment: A priest from Samaria returns to teach the resettled population about the LORD.

secondaryrefs.comment: Amos, from Judah, is sent to the northern kingdom of Israel.

primaryrefs.comment: Healing and deliverance accompanies preaching as part of the disciples' mission.

seealsos.comment: During Jesus Christ's earthly ministry the disciples' mission was limited to Israel
Philip
Apollos
Paul
Peter and Andrew
Philip
Paul

children.title: The call confirmed by the church

seealsos.comment: Paul's call to be a missionary to the Gentiles is communicated through Ananias
Paul's mission to the Gentiles is recognised by the other apostles.

primaryrefs.comment: Persecution drove the early church to wider mission.

seealsos.comment: Joseph sold into slavery in Egypt
Daniel among those taken into exile in Babylon
Priscilla and Aquila left Rome because of persecution.

children.title: missionaries, task of
children.comment: God commits various tasks to his servants. A principal task of those sent by God is to take the good news of the gospel to those who have not heard it, and so to be a means through which others come to faith.

children.title: Calling people to turn to God

secondaryrefs.comment: Moses is sent by God to Pharoah
The eastern tribes complete their mission to help the others take possession of Canaan
Gideon is sent by God against the Midianites
Saul is given the task of destroying the Amalekites
Samuel is sent by God to anoint David as king
Cyrus is appointed to bring deliverance from Babylon.

children.title: missionaries, support for
children.comment: Though facing hardships, missionaries receive strength from God to enable them to carry out their task. They are entitled, too, to receive support, encouragement and financial assistance from other believers.

children.title: The Holy Spirit gives power to witness
Missionaries supported by the sending church
Missionary work supported by church leaders
Missionaries encouraged by visits and news

ordination
children.comment: The appointment to a public ministry or office, including investing with the authority required for this ministry. The most important biblical model of ordination is provided by the OT priesthood.

cschildren.title: Ordination of the OT priesthood

children.title: The role of the ordained priest
children.precomment: To properly apply the blood of the ordination offering:

secondaryrefs.comment: to make atonement
to observe a strict code of behaviour

cschildren.title: Jesus is the Messiah, the anointed one

secondaryrefs.comment: The Greek word ``Christos'', like the Hebrew word ``Messiah'', means ``anointed (by God)''.

cschildren.title: Ordination in the NT

children.title: Jesus Christ appointed disciples without reference to a ceremony of ordination
The apostles commissioned people for service by laying on of hands

seealsos.comment: Barnabas and Saul were commissioned for missionary work.

secondaryrefs.comment: Certain qualities are required in an appointed elder or minister.

children.title: overseers
children.comment: In the OT a variety of supervisory roles are mentioned. In the NT ``overseers'' (traditionally translated ``bishops'') describes the role of local church leaders.

cschildren.title: Overseers in the OT
Overseers in the NT

primaryrefs.comment: A title for local church leaders.
Here, as elsewhere in the NT, ``elders'' and ``overseers'' are virtually synonymous.

children.title: persuasion
children.comment: Attempting to win others over to one's own point of view. It can be either positive, as with preaching the gospel, or it can spring from a malign intent to seduce people from the truth.

cschildren.title: Means of persuasion
The first Christians were persuaded of the truth of their faith
The apostles tried to persuade others of the truth of the gospel
Scripture advises patience when seeking to persuade those in power
Scripture warns against the persuasiveness of evil
Examples of God's servants suffering through the persuasiveness of others

children.title: preaching
children.comment: The announcing of the good news of God by his servants through the faithful revelation of God's will, the exposition of God's word and the proclamation of Jesus Christ, the Son of God. Jesus Christ had an important preaching ministry.

children.title: preaching, importance of
children.comment: Preaching has a central place among God's people and is vital to their life and growth. It is authorised by God, empowered by the Holy Spirit and expressed supremely by Jesus Christ.

children.title: Preaching has its origin in God
It is rooted in God's grace
It is empowered by God's Spirit
The importance of preaching and Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ himself came to preach
Jesus Christ's own ministry involved much preaching
Jesus Christ commissioned his disciples to preach
The importance of preaching and the church
It is a natural part of the church's life
It is a trust from God
It is an integral aspect of key ministries in the church
The importance of preaching for salvation
The importance of preaching means preachers and teachers will be judged more strictly
preaching, content of
children.comment: Preaching is centred on the nature and will of God and his claims on all people. Expressed in prophecy, declaration or teaching, it includes the proclamation of the way of salvation to unbelievers and instruction about the faith to believers.

children.title: Preaching and the revelation of God's character, word and will
Preaching and the declaration of the gospel
Declaring the person of Jesus Christ and his life
Declaring the facts of the cross and the resurrection
Declaring the victory and exaltation of Jesus Christ
Declaring that Jesus is both Messiah (Christ) and Lord
Preaching finds expression in the teaching of believers
The central place of teaching in the lives of the first Christians
Preaching and the edification of believers
Preaching and the continuation of apostolic doctrine
Preaching should be rooted in apostolic doctrine, which is to be faithfully handed on
Preaching that does not conform to apostolic doctrine is to be rejected
Preaching and the rejection of merely human wisdom
preaching, effects of
children.comment: Faithful preaching leads to, through the grace of God, the repentance of sinners, the birth of faith and the nourishment of believers. It can also evoke hostility from unbelievers.

children.title: It depends upon the grace of God
It depends upon the power of the cross, not human wisdom
It depends upon the power of the Holy Spirit
It needs to be received with faith
Preaching and the repentance of sinners
Preaching and the birth of faith
Preaching and the nourishment of believers
Effective preaching and its authentication by miracles

secondaryrefs.comment: Paul in Athens and before the Areopagus
Paul before Felix and Drusilla

children.title: preachers, call of
children.comment: God declares his word through called and anointed preachers. He overcomes their reluctance, helps their weakness, authorises their message and confirms the truth of what they declare.

children.title: It is not dependent upon background
It is not dependent upon ability
It is not dependent upon willingness
It is a matter of God's sovereign choice
They are commissioned to declare God's word
They are to declare God's word with authority
They are to declare God's word without fear
God's confirmation of his call upon preachers
preachers, qualifications for
children.comment: Those entrusted with the task of preaching must ensure that their lives are in line with their message. They must be of good character and conduct, be consistent in all they teach and do and be accountable to others.

children.title: Preachers must be of good character

seealsos.comment: That the judgment is based on character, and not just on teaching, seems clear from the references to guarding the tongue which follow.

children.title: Preachers must practise what they preach
Preachers must be accountable to others and to God
Preachers must not look for honour for themselves
Preachers must not look for personal gain
Preachers must be people of integrity
preachers, responsibilities of
children.comment: Those entrusted with the responsibility of preaching are to discharge it faithfully, boldly and persistently in the power of the Holy Spirit. The Christian community should honour faithful preachers and challenge those who fail to honour their responsibility.

children.title: They must be diligent in their preaching
They must be faithful in their preaching
They must be persistent in their preaching
They must be bold in their preaching
They must be encouraging in their preaching
They must be filled with the Holy Spirit
They must be compassionate in their preaching
The responsibilities of the church towards preachers
Unfaithful preachers are to be exposed and will be judged
preaching, importance of
children.comment: Preaching has a central place among God's people and is vital to their life and growth. It is authorised by God, empowered by the Holy Spirit and expressed supremely by Jesus Christ.

children.title: Preaching has its origin in God
It is rooted in God's grace
It is empowered by God's Spirit
The importance of preaching and Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ himself came to preach
Jesus Christ's own ministry involved much preaching
Jesus Christ commissioned his disciples to preach
The importance of preaching and the church
It is a natural part of the church's life
It is a trust from God
It is an integral aspect of key ministries in the church
The importance of preaching for salvation
The importance of preaching means preachers and teachers will be judged more strictly
preaching, content of
children.comment: Preaching is centred on the nature and will of God and his claims on all people. Expressed in prophecy, declaration or teaching, it includes the proclamation of the way of salvation to unbelievers and instruction about the faith to believers.

children.title: Preaching and the revelation of God's character, word and will
Preaching and the declaration of the gospel
Declaring the person of Jesus Christ and his life
Declaring the facts of the cross and the resurrection
Declaring the victory and exaltation of Jesus Christ
Declaring that Jesus is both Messiah (Christ) and Lord
Preaching finds expression in the teaching of believers
The central place of teaching in the lives of the first Christians
Preaching and the edification of believers
Preaching and the continuation of apostolic doctrine
Preaching should be rooted in apostolic doctrine, which is to be faithfully handed on
Preaching that does not conform to apostolic doctrine is to be rejected
Preaching and the rejection of merely human wisdom

priests
children.comment: A group of men charged with the responsibility of mediating between God and his people, ensuring proper worship, and maintaining the spiritual health of the people of God.

children.title: priests, institution in OT times
children.comment: Priests played an important role in the OT and were regarded as having a special status and place in the life of Israel.

children.title: Associated with the descendants of Levi through Aaron
The exclusive nature of the priesthood

primaryrefs.comment: Only God has the right to nominate those who mediate between him and humanity.

seealsos.comment: This genealogy shows Moses and Aaron were both descended from Levi

children.title: Criticism of priestly appointments that were not Levitical

seealsos.comment: Kings and priests also were anointed.

children.title: priests, function in OT times
children.comment: Priests had a unique role: administering the sanctuary, offering sacrifice and leading and teaching the people. Accordingly they were set apart by a special code of conduct.

children.title: They were consecrated to the LORD
They were not to incur uncleanness

primaryrefs.comment: Some exceptions to uncleanness by touching a corpse are listed in verses 2-3.

children.title: They were not to shave or mutilate themselves
They were not to marry any but a virtuous Israelite
They were not to drink wine before entering the sanctuary
They were disqualified by physical defects
They were not to allow outsiders to eat the sacred offerings
They were not to own land in Israel
They were not to offer unacceptable sacrifices
They were to obey God's law meticulously
They only had access to holy things
priests, types of in NT times
children.comment: The NT points to the fulfilment of the OT priesthood in Jesus Christ, and develops the idea that all Christian believers can be seen as priests. It also records the continuing role of priests in the life of Israel and pagan nations at this time.

primaryrefs.comment: The Sadducees were a conservative party composed entirely of priests who were influential in the Sanhedrin.
Levites were closely associated with priests as temple personnel, perhaps mentioned here because of their teaching function.

children.title: priests, tasks in NT times
children.comment: The priests mentioned in the NT performed various functions, all of which are fulfilled in Jesus Christ and the church, which is his body.

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ is both priest and victim: his own body takes the place occupied by sacrifices in the OT ritual.

children.title: The Christian sacrifice of a surrendered life
They were trained in the teaching and application of OT law
Priests declared people clean or unclean
They supplied ritual certification of cleansing
priests, institution in OT times
children.comment: Priests played an important role in the OT and were regarded as having a special status and place in the life of Israel.

children.title: Associated with the descendants of Levi through Aaron

prophets
children.comment: Individuals called and empowered by God to declare his will to his people, including the disclosure of his future intentions to save and judge his people. The term refers particularly to the great OT prophets, such as Isaiah and Jeremiah, who were raised up to guide the people of God at critical moments in their history and whose ministries and teaching remain of continuing importance today. At several points in his ministry, Jesus Christ was acclaimed as a prophet.

children.title: prophets, role of
children.comment: As agents of God, prophets acted in various capacities, as was required of them, in order to carry out his will and fulfil his purpose.

children.title: They conveyed messages from God to the nations

seealsos.comment: the birth of Immanuel

primaryrefs.comment: The intermediary role of the prophet is highlighted by the image of a watchman who receives messages from God and conveys them to the people.

children.title: Prophets as leaders in the community
prophets, false
children.comment: Men or women who falsely claim to speak on God's behalf. They are denounced in the OT and NT for leading people astray. Scripture provides criteria by which true prophets may be recognised and distinguished from false prophets, who often speak from base motives.

children.title: A true prophet's word will be fulfilled
A true prophet's teaching commends righteous behaviour
A true prophet's godly life will reflect his calling
A true prophet will acknowledge Jesus Christ as divine
Their messages may be occasioned by popular demand
Their messages may be given for financial reward
Their messages may be the result of deception
Their messages may be inspired by divination
prophets, lives of
children.comment: God called individuals from differing backgrounds to speak as prophets on his behalf, sometimes in difficult circumstances.

secondaryrefs.comment: Moses was brought up in the Egyptian royal court
Samuel was a temple servant at Shiloh
Elisha was a farmer
Ezekiel was a priest living in exile in Babylonia.

children.title: The family life of the prophets

secondaryrefs.comment: Moses
Samuel
Elijah did not die but was taken up in a chariot of fire.

children.title: school of prophets
children.comment: A company of prophets working and prophesying together under the instruction and leadership of a more experienced prophet. There were also similar companies of false prophets.

cschildren.title: A school of prophets used by God to influence others
Schools of prophets associated with particular places
Leaders of schools of prophets

children.title: Samuel and a school of prophets
Elisha and a school of prophets

cschildren.title: A school of prophets in danger
Schools of false prophets
Seer as an alternative title for a prophet

primaryrefs.comment: Literally, a ``seer'' is ``one who sees'', especially one who claims to see into the future or to have insight into the will of God.

cschildren.title: Seers used by people to enquire of God

children.title: David had seers to enquire of God for him

cschildren.title: Seers were used by God to bring his word to the people
Seers were used by God to bring his word to the king
The words of a seer were sometimes unwelcome
Samuel was called a seer
Asaph, the psalmist, called a seer
Seers wrote Israel's history
God judges Israel by blinding the seers

children.title: shepherd
children.comment: The work of a shepherd was important and responsible in the rural world of ancient Palestine. Since it involved leading, protecting and feeding a flock, it is seen as a metaphor for the task of leadership. Scripture declares that God is the Shepherd of his people.

children.title: shepherd, as occupation
children.comment: The occupation of a shepherd was both humble and honourable. In the marginal hill country of Palestine it was particularly demanding.

children.title: A shepherd as a keeper of flocks of animals

secondaryrefs.comment: The Hebrew word refers to a keeper of goats and cattle as well as sheep.

seealsos.comment: The rod is a crook (for extracting sheep from difficulty) and the staff a club (for warding off wild animals)

children.title: The use of pens and folds
Rearing
children.precomment: Rebekah's ruse depended on a method used to get a ewe to accept an alien lamb:

secondaryrefs.comment: A shepherd who lost an animal to wild beasts had to produce evidence

children.title: shepherd, as king and leader
children.comment: Shepherd was a standard term for a leader or king throughout the ancient world. In this sense it often appears in the Bible.

children.title: General term for a king or leader

primaryrefs.comment: The prophet describes this non-Jewish king as God's shepherd

children.title: David as the model of a good shepherd

seealsos.comment: The king is brought to his senses by a ``shepherd'' story

children.title: The shepherd faces death for his flock
David as a model of the coming Messiah
A good shepherd as a leader ``after God's own heart''
Criticisms of the shepherds of Israel
shepherd, as church leader
children.comment: Church leaders are likened to shepherds, on account of their pastoral responsibilities and tasks.

children.comment: The occupation of a shepherd was both humble and honourable. In the marginal hill country of Palestine it was particularly demanding.

shepherd, as church leader
children.comment: Church leaders are likened to shepherds, on account of their pastoral responsibilities and tasks.

children.title: teachers
children.comment: Those who have responsibility for instructing others, especially in relation to matters of faith and life: in the home, parents; in Israel, priests and teachers of the law and in the NT church, apostles, prophets, pastors and teachers. At a less formal level Christians should seek to teach one another. God is the supreme teacher of his people.

cschildren.title: God is the supreme teacher
Parents as teachers
Priests as Israel's teachers
The apostles and their helpers as teachers
The gift of teachers in the church
Elders as teachers
Christians as teachers of one another

children.title: teaching
children.comment: The act of instructing someone in matters of faith and morals, especially in the home or church. Teaching was a major aspect of the ministry of Jesus Christ.

children.title: teaching
children.comment: The apostles' teaching formed the basis of the instruction given to the first Christians. Parts of the NT draw a distinction between preaching and teaching, seeing the former as a means of converting individuals, and the latter as a means of instructing them after conversion.

primaryrefs.comment: ``goads'' prod the sluggish to action, while ``embedded nails'' furnish a kind of mental anchorage. ``Shepherd'' is almost certainly a reference to God himself.

children.title: The gift of teaching in the church
Through the instruction of different groups within the church
The distinction between teaching and preaching
Examples of major themes taught in the NT church
Righteousness from God through faith in Jesus Christ
Freedom in Christ from the demands of the law

primaryrefs.comment: Hebrews also shows Jesus Christ to be superior to the angels, the high priest and the sacrifices.
